title: 105_hr2970
content: The "National Historic Lighthouse Preservation Act of 1997" is introduced to amend the National Historic Preservation Act by adding a new section for the preservation of historic light stations. The Secretary is tasked with collecting and sharing information on historic light stations, promoting educational programs, conducting research, maintaining a listing of historic light stations, and evaluating the program's effectiveness. Additionally, within a year of the Act's enactment, historic light stations are to be conveyed. The National Historic Lighthouse Preservation Act of 1997 requires the Secretary and the Administrator of General Services to establish a process for identifying and selecting an eligible entity to convey a historic light station for various purposes. The Secretary reviews applicants for conveyance of excess historic light stations and consults with the State Historic Preservation Officer when selecting an eligible entity. The National Historic Lighthouse Preservation Act of 1997 mandates the conveyance of historic light stations to eligible entities. The Administrator will transfer ownership to selected entities in partnership with public or nonprofit organizations focused on preservation, without cost and subject to specific conditions. The National Historic Lighthouse Preservation Act of 1997 requires the transfer of historic light stations to eligible entities without cost, subject to specific conditions for continued operation and maintenance by the United States. The National Historic Lighthouse Preservation Act of 1997 allows the transfer of historic light stations to eligible entities at no cost, with conditions for maintenance and operation by the United States. The eligible entity must maintain the property according to the Act, Secretary's Historic Preservation Standards, and other laws. The United States retains the right to relocate, replace, or add aids to navigation as needed for navigation purposes, and can enter the property for maintenance without notice. The conveyance of a historic light station under the National Historic Lighthouse Preservation Act of 1997 includes conditions for maintenance and operation by eligible entities. The Secretary, Administrator, and eligible entity are not required to maintain active aids to navigation associated with the historic light station. The property may revert to the United States if it ceases to be available for education, park, or recreation purposes. The property may revert to the United States if it ceases to be available for education, park, recreation, cultural, historic preservation, or national security purposes. Maintenance and compliance with preservation standards are also required. The legal description of any historic light station and associated property conveyed under this section will be determined by the Administrator. The Administrator may retain ownership of historical artifacts like lenses or lanterns. Conveyees must use and maintain the light station according to specified terms and conditions. The term 'historic light station' includes various structures and land, with specific criteria for age and listing. An 'eligible entity' can be a government agency, nonprofit, educational agency, or community development organization. An eligible entity must comply with conditions, maintain the light station financially, and indemnify the Federal Government for any losses or expenses related to the property. SEC. 3. SALE OF SURPLUS LIGHT STATIONS. The historic light station will be offered for sale if no applicants are approved for conveyance. Terms of sale will be determined by the Administrator of General Services with covenants to protect historical integrity. Sale proceeds will go to the National Maritime Heritage Grant Program. SEC. 4. TRANSFER OF HISTORIC LIGHT STATIONS TO FEDERAL AGENCIES. SEC. 4. TRANSFER OF HISTORIC LIGHT STATIONS TO FEDERAL AGENCIES. Any federal agency receiving a historic light station must maintain it according to preservation standards and laws.
